instructions_t_articles.text_1_facilitator::eng:
Focus on the positive!

Telling our teens what we DO want them to do works better than telling them to STOP doing something.

You will see the difference.
instructions_t_articles.media_transcript::eng:
Greetings, greetings everyone.

Today our topic is positive instructions.

It is important to give positive instructions to our children, because when we give them positive instructions they know and understand what we are expecting them to do and they do it the way we want them to do it.

So, at the end it keeps everyone happy.

instructions_t_articles.text_1_facilitator::eng: Here's what parents have to say about giving positive instructions
instructions_t_articles.media_transcript::eng:
Before, I used to raise my teens the way I was raised: I would tell them ‚Äúdon‚Äôt do this, don‚Äôt do that.‚Äù We used to fight a lot, but things have really changed when I learnt about giving positive instructions.

Now I focus on the behaviour I want to see, and give clear and simple instructions to my teens. It took time to learn to say ‚Äúplease do this‚Äù instead of ‚Äúdon‚Äôt do this.‚Äù

My teens and even my husband tell me that they love this way of doing things, because now they know what needs to be done. My teen said one day ‚ÄúI really love this new mom,‚Äù and my own stress levels have come down a lot.

instructions_t_articles.text_1_facilitator::eng:
Let‚Äôs do a thought experiment!

DO NOT THINK ABOUT AN ELEPHANT

What are you thinking about? 

You probably DID think about an elephant...
‚ÄòDon‚Äôt do‚Äô instructions make teens think about that thing.
Sometimes they do not understand what we DID want from them.
Also they often don‚Äôt like being told not to do things (just like most of us).

NOW, THINK ABOUT A CHEETAH!

What are you thinking about?

That‚Äôs right! Positive, clear instructions help teens focus on what they should be doing.

Teens will also feel more respected this way and are more likely to listen.
Let‚Äôs see what happens if @data.characters.f2_grandmother.name tells @data.characters.f2_daughter_17.name  "DON'T":

But I need to practise for the school competition. You never let me do anything.

instructions_t_articles.text_1_facilitator::eng:
Here are this week‚Äôs takeaway skills!

Use them at home and find them anytime in your Parent Library.
instructions_t_articles.section_1_text::eng: Can your teen actually do what you are about to ask? It may be impossible for them to read quietly all day, but half an hour when you really need it is realistic.
instructions_t_articles.section_2_text::eng: Smile, look them in the eye and use positive words. Praise them as soon as they start to do what you ask!
instructions_t_articles.section_3_text::eng: Often we know what we want in our head, but we don‚Äôt say it clearly enough. Say exactly what you want your teen to do. Try ‚Äòplease come home by 7pm‚Äô instead of ‚Äòcome home in time‚Äô.

instructions_t_articles.text_1_facilitator::eng: Small actions, big results! Parents who practice their module skills at home get better results.
instructions_t_articles.text_2::eng: Remember ‚Äì GET REAL, GET POSITIVE, GET CLEAR = GET EXACTLY WHAT YOU WANT (as much as is possible with a teenager!)

instructions_t_articles.quiz_2_feedback_2::eng: That‚Äôs great music. Who is the singer? Please turn the music off when you come in the house. You can play it in your room quietly if you want. Thank you!

instructions_t_articles.media_transcript::eng:
At first, I did not care much that my mother was doing ParentApp. But then I started to see my mother change how she communicated with us.

One day, when I was going out with my friends, she said I must be home by 6pm. I was like ‚ÄúHmmm okay,‚Äù because she normally did not give clear instructions on what she wanted ‚Äì she would just say nothing and then shout at me for being late when I got home.

When I got home around 5pm, my mother gave me a hug and said ‚ÄúThank you for being on time.‚Äù It was strange, but I liked it.

Since then, we have much clearer communication in the house.

selfcare_articles.text_1_facilitator::eng:
Today's topic is about taking care of yourself 

We often forget to take care of ourselves, but it's really important, especially if you are a parent!

When we lower our stress and treat ourselves kindly, it helps both us and our children.
selfcare_articles.media_title::eng: How does taking care of myself help me and my family?
selfcare_articles.media_transcript::eng:
Greetings, everyone.

There are times when we experience challenges, face problems, and do not know what to do. It is important to take care of ourselves every day, so we are ready to handle those times well and stay calm. 

When we are calm, we are in a good state to think positively and come up with positive solutions to any challenges we may be facing.

selfcare_articles.character_1_text::eng: Alright, @data.characters.f1_daughter_6.name, let me finish dinner quickly, and then I will come play with you.

(ü§î_thinking_) What a day. I have a lot on my plate, but I am still standing and trying my best every day. Tomorrow, I should visit with my friends so we can catch up and be reminded that we aren't alone!

selfcare_articles.section_1_text::eng: Taking a pause helps us to feel and respond calmer in stressful moments.
selfcare_articles.section_1_extra_text::eng:
Even taking a few deep breaths makes a big difference. 

By staying calm instead of reacting strongly, you can also prevent a lot of problems!
selfcare_articles.section_2_text::eng: Take a moment and think of one thing YOU did well recently. Say it aloud if you can: "Well done for ‚Ä¶"
selfcare_articles.section_2_extra_text::eng:
Being a parent can be hard. Praise yourself for trying your best. 

Identify negative thoughts when they start and decide if they are true or helpful. If not, find positive thoughts to replace them with. 

For example, instead of ‚ÄúI am a bad parent‚Äù say ‚ÄúI am feeling overwhelmed right now, but I am doing the best I can and I will talk to a friend for support‚Äù.
selfcare_articles.section_3_text::eng: What makes you happy? Find small things that you can do every day to care for yourself.
selfcare_articles.section_3_extra_text::eng: Doing something you enjoy will give you a short break. It will help you to think more clearly and care better for your family. Caring for yourself = caring your family!

childdevelopment_articles.text_1_facilitator::eng:
Today's topic is about helping your child learn and grow. 

Playing with your child is important for their growth and learning, both in and out of school. This is true for all children, including those with disabilities.

Did you know that playing helps your child learn what is expected and how to get along with others?

Children learn a lot by asking questions. Support their interests and curiosity, and be patient when they make mistakes. We all learn from our mistakes!
childdevelopment_articles.media_title::eng: How will it help me and my family?
childdevelopment_articles.media_transcript::eng:
Hello!
Do you know that children learn best through playing? 

And let‚Äôs be honest, which child does not like to play? 

Learning takes time, but there is a lot that you can do as a parent to help your child. Let them play and explore. Let them ask questions and learn from mistakes. And be patient. Your support will help them grow and develop.

childdevelopment_articles.section_1_text::eng:
Play is the main way children learn and develop. Through play, they build important physical and social skills. 

Set aside time to play games with your child, be creative, and have fun together.
childdevelopment_articles.section_1_extra_text::eng:
Through play, you also learn what kind of support your child may need.

Support your child to play and make friends with other children, so they learn how to interact with others well. 

If your child starts to feel overwhelmed with anything in their day, help them reduce their stress by taking a pause and playing together.
childdevelopment_articles.section_2_text::eng:
Learning new things takes time. Be patient and encourage your child to keep trying things they may find hard. 

Stay calm when they get angry or frustrated - your child will learn to do the same over time.
childdevelopment_articles.section_2_extra_text::eng:
You can support them by praising them for trying and helping them break large tasks into smaller tasks appropriate for their age.

Use play to help your child learn difficult skills, like losing, sharing, or taking turns.
childdevelopment_articles.section_3_text::eng:
Children learn by asking questions and exploring the things they are interested in. Give your child time and space to do this. 

Join your child‚Äôs activities and ask them questions to encourage them to learn more.
childdevelopment_articles.section_3_extra_text::eng:
Your child may talk a lot and have many questions - including difficult ones. You can give your child short but honest answers. 

If you need a break or more information, you can take a pause and tell your child you will respond to them later.

childdevelopment_articles.media_title::eng: How it helped a parent like you:
childdevelopment_articles.media_transcript::eng:
I thought that my daughter only started learning when she went to school. 

@global.app_name gave me lots of ideas for what I could do to help her develop at home. By playing together, we were able to practise many words in a fun way. She is speaking much more now, and we are closer because of the time we spend together.

childdevelopment_articles.text_1_facilitator::eng:
Want to help your child develop and grow?

Invite your child to play with you today. Encourage them to ask questions and explore new things through play.

oneononetime_articles.text_1_facilitator::eng:
Today we are learning about spending one-on-one time with your child. 

Spending dedicated, special, time with your child will make them feel valued and loved.
It will also build trust and respect, and support their learning.
oneononetime_articles.media_title::eng: How will it help me and my family?
oneononetime_articles.media_transcript::eng:
Greetings!

It turns out that our children don‚Äôt need lots of gifts. The best gift we can give them is to spend time with them.

Spending time together just the two of you will help you to understand your child better and help them to l learn new things.

Having this time together with your child will feel special because it will help them feel loved and valued. And that will make everything easier at home!

oneononetime_articles.text_1_facilitator::eng: Here are some easy tips on how to connect with your child when you spend time together:
oneononetime_articles.section_1_text::eng: Spend at least 5 minutes with your child each day. More is better!
oneononetime_articles.section_2_text::eng: Switch off the TV, put aside phones, and remove distractions. Show your child that you are really paying attention to them.
oneononetime_articles.section_2_extra_text::eng:
- Look at your child. Get down to their level. Use their name.
- Describe what they are doing and feeling. Praise them.
- Your child will learn a lot from what you say and do.
oneononetime_articles.section_3_text::eng:
Ask to spend time with your child. Let them choose what to do or talk about. 
Try different activities together. Have fun!
oneononetime_articles.section_3_extra_text::eng: This will help your child feel important and valued.

oneononetime_articles.media_title::eng: How it helped a parent like you:
oneononetime_articles.media_transcript::eng:
When I first heard I have to spend one-on-one time with my daughter, it was hard for me. I did not know when to do it or what to say. I did not want to spoil my daughter so that she thinks we have to do everything together. 

But I really wanted to build my relationship with her and I wanted her to open up about what was troubling her. 

So we tried the One-on-One Time. 

First, it felt weird, but it turned out to be fun! Now we play her favourite game together and talk about things happening at school and with her friends.

oneononetime_articles.text_1_facilitator::eng:
Ready to try it out? 

Spend 5 minutes (or more) of one-on-one time with your child, every day.

praise_articles.text_1_facilitator::eng:
Today we are learning about giving our children praise. 

Praise is good for building positive relationships, and is also helpful at encouraging good behaviour!

Well done for taking time to learn how to strengthen your relationship with your child. It shows you really care!
praise_articles.quiz_1_question::eng: How did the message above make you feel?
praise_articles.quiz_1_feedback_1::eng: That's great! Being praised often makes us feel proud.
praise_articles.quiz_1_feedback_2::eng: That's great! Being praised often makes us feel happy!
praise_articles.quiz_1_feedback_3::eng: Sometimes being praised makes us feel embarrassed, usually because we are not used to it. It will get easier with practice! Giving praise helps children learn the behaviours you want to see.
praise_articles.quiz_1_feedback_4::eng: Sometimes, when we are praised for actions that we don't feel we deserve, we get sad. It is okay to feel sad, but remember that just being here is worthy of praise! Keep your chin up!

praise_articles.text_1_facilitator::eng:
We all feel better when we are praised.

Praising your child when they behave well will make them want to behave that way more often. 

It also creates a positive and loving relationship between you.

Begin by praising your child during your one-on-one time.
praise_articles.media_title::eng: How will it help me and my family?
praise_articles.media_transcript::eng:
Greetings, everyone.

When was the last time you were praised? Can you praise yourself for something right now? Praise makes us all feel good. 

It is good to praise our children when they have done well, because when we do that, they will do more of that good behaviour we want to see.

And let's remember to praise ourselves too, for big or small things!

praise_articles.text_1_facilitator::eng: Here are some easy tips for how to use praise and rewards:
praise_articles.section_1_text::eng: Be on the lookout for good behaviour! When offering praise, focus on anything positive or helpful your child does or attempts to do.
praise_articles.section_1_extra_text::eng:
Pause and really notice when they are doing something positive. Even if it‚Äôs expected of them.

Praise your child for *trying*. This boosts their self-esteem and confidence, which helps them to learn new behaviours.
praise_articles.section_2_text::eng: Praise them when you see them do something you like. Do this every day ‚Äì even if it‚Äôs something really small.
praise_articles.section_2_extra_text::eng:
Tell them specifically what they have done well.

Be enthusiastic and really mean it!

You can show your praise with a big smile and words.
praise_articles.section_3_text::eng: Give your child a simple, free reward to encourage them to do more of the behaviours that you have praised them for.
praise_articles.section_3_extra_text::eng:
Rewards should be simple and free. 

Give your child a hug, extra playtime together, or make their favourite meal. 

Simple rewards can be a big motivation for your child to keep trying and show more positive behaviour.

praise_articles.text_1_facilitator::eng: Curious to see how praise can help you and your family?
praise_articles.media_title::eng: How it helped a parent like you:
praise_articles.media_transcript::eng:
When we learned about this praising thing, I thought ‚ÄúWe were never praised for things as children, so why should we start now?‚Äù. But I got interested when I learned what the benefits of praising could be.

Right after learning about praise, I noticed my son doing what he does every day: Packing away his toys after playing. And I said ‚ÄúThank you for packing away your toys, my boy, it really makes me happy that you are helping out to keep the house tidy.‚Äù My son was smiling and he even came to give me a hug, which he never does. 

This praising business is hard. I still forget to do it sometimes. But praising really makes a difference. I never thought that a simple praise could make such a change in a person!

feelings_articles.text_1_facilitator::eng:
Today we are learning to talk about feelings with our children. 

Noticing  emotions, both our own and our children's, helps us care for ourselves. 

Noticing and talking about feelings with our children helps them learn to express and manage their emotions ‚Äì even the difficult ones.
feelings_articles.media_title::eng: How will it help me and my family?
feelings_articles.media_transcript::eng:
Greetings, everyone.

Does your child ever get so upset that you don‚Äôt know what to do? 

You can help your child to manage their emotions better by showing them how to talk about their feelings. In order to talk about feelings you need to first notice and then accept all the emotions we have.

feelings_articles.text_1_facilitator::eng: Let‚Äôs check in on another family to see how talking about feelings helps them in a practical way:

feelings_articles.text_1_facilitator::eng: With these three tips, you can help your child learn to manage their emotions well.
feelings_articles.section_1_text::eng: Recognise the *positive* and *difficult* emotions that you and your child feel.
feelings_articles.section_1_extra_text::eng: To recognise feelings, pay attention to your thoughts and to your and your child‚Äôs words and actions.
feelings_articles.section_2_text::eng: Be open to how you and your child feel. All feelings are okay.
feelings_articles.section_2_extra_text::eng:
There are six basic emotions. Each send us an important message:
 üòä Happy: Keep doing things that make you feel good. 

‚òπÔ∏è Sad: Something important in your life needs attention.

üò† Angry: Stand up for yourself and set limits.

ü§¢ Disgusted: Move away from something you don't like.

üòØ Surprised: Stop and pay attention for a moment.

üò® Afraid: Run away from danger.
 
As children get older, they learn to identify lots of other emotions, like feeling excited, frustrated, proud, lonely, peaceful, guilty, or confused.
feelings_articles.section_3_text::eng:
Use words to describe your and your child‚Äôs emotions, so they can learn to do the same. 
 
This may be hard at first, but it is an important step to help manage emotions!
feelings_articles.section_3_extra_text::eng:
Describe how you see your child‚Äôs emotion in a calm way. For example:
 
*‚ÄúI notice you‚Äôre stomping your feet, talking loudly, and your face looks a bit upset. Are you feeling angry?‚Äù*
 
Share your own feelings with your child. For example: 
 
*‚ÄúI know I feel the same way when I can‚Äôt go out when I want to.‚Äù*
 
This shows your child that it's okay to share their feelings. They will learn to recognise emotions in themselves and others too.

feelings_articles.text_1_facilitator::eng: Let‚Äôs put the tips you have learnt in action:
feelings_articles.media_title::eng: How it helped a parent like you:
feelings_articles.media_transcript::eng:
My daughter used to get so frustrated and angry when she did not get her way. She would shout and scream, even when we went out, and I would also feel very angry and embarrassed. 

When I learned about emotions, I started to name and acknowledge her emotions. I helped her understand that it is okay to feel angry sometimes, but that she can show it in a different way. Now, she will tell me when she starts to feel angry, and we can find a solution together that works for everyone.
feelings_articles.quiz_1_question::eng: @data.characters.f1_mother.name's son is throwing a tantrum at the front door. It's time to put on his shoes and the family is running late. Tying his shoes is a challenge and he wants to do it himself. How can @data.characters.f1_mother.name respond?
feelings_articles.quiz_1_option_1_text::eng: Tie his shoes for him and get out the door. We are late!
feelings_articles.quiz_1_feedback_1::eng: It is never fun to run late, but @data.characters.f1_mother.name will miss the opportunity to help her son learn to deal with his frustration if she doesn't help him first recognise what he‚Äôs feeling.
feelings_articles.quiz_1_option_2_text::eng: Understand that her son is feeling frustrated. Sit down and help him name his feelings.
feelings_articles.quiz_1_feedback_2::eng: That's a great idea. She can also commit to practising shoe tying with him later, when he's more calm and praise him for naming his feelings and for the good effort during their practise session!

feelings_articles.text_1_facilitator::eng: Your home activity is to talk with your child about their feelings during one-on-one time today. It can be something simple, like noticing that they find joy when they play!
feelings_articles.quiz_1_question::eng: Are you up for trying? Can you help your child notice their feelings during one-on-one time today?
feelings_articles.quiz_1_feedback_1::eng: That's great! It might be awkward to talk about feelings at first, but it will get better for everyone with practice.
feelings_articles.quiz_1_feedback_2::eng: That's okay. Learning to share emotions with our children can be challenging. Take a minute after one-on-one time today to think through the emotions you saw your child display. You might also want to think about the things that you felt!

instructions_articles.text_1_facilitator::eng:
Today's lesson is about learning to give instructions that work! 

Nobody follows rules all of the time. But *how* we give instructions can make things more happy and calm at home.

Negative instructions like, ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt touch that!‚Äù can make children feel bad. (They can make parents feel bad, too!)

Children are more likely to follow an instruction when it is worded in a positive way: "Please only touch things that belong to us!"
instructions_articles.media_title::eng: How will this help me and my family?
instructions_articles.media_transcript::eng:
Let‚Äôs try something: Don‚Äôt think about a pink elephant‚Ä¶
What did you think about? A pink elephant?

The same happens when we give negative instructions to our children. When we tell them ‚Äústop fighting‚Äù or ‚Äústop playing with your food‚Äù, they don‚Äôt know how to think about what we DO want them to do, only what we DON‚ÄôT want them to do.‚Äù

When you give a positive instruction, your child is more likely to follow it.

instructions_articles.text_2::eng: @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name is playing with the blocks on the floor.
instructions_articles.character_1_text::eng: It looks like you‚Äôre having a lot of fun, @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name. It‚Äôs almost time to clean up. In 3 minutes, please put your blocks away.
3 minutes are over, @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name. Please pack away your blocks.
Thank you very much for packing away the blocks when I asked you, @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name. Because you listened so well, I will read you an extra story before bed.

instructions_articles.text_1_facilitator::eng: Let‚Äôs reflect on what we can learn from @data.characters.f1_mother.name and @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name.
instructions_articles.quiz_1_question::eng: How does @data.characters.f1_mother.name connect with @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name before giving an instruction?
instructions_articles.quiz_1_feedback_1::eng: She does say her daughter‚Äôs name, but she also goes down to @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name‚Äôs level, and gives her praise.
instructions_articles.quiz_1_option_2_text::eng: She reminds @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name that she has a responsibility to keep her toys clean.
instructions_articles.quiz_1_feedback_2::eng: Try again! @data.characters.f1_mother.name does not just give an instruction right away, she first makes sure @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name feels seen!

instructions_articles.quiz_1_feedback_3::eng: Try again! @data.characters.f1_mother.name first connects with her daughter by saying her name, getting down at her level, and giving her praise. This puts her in the best position to then give @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name an instruction.
instructions_articles.quiz_2_question::eng: What steps does @data.characters.f1_mother.name take to help @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name follow her instruction?
instructions_articles.quiz_2_option_1_text::eng: She warns @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name that misbehaviour is not acceptable.
instructions_articles.quiz_2_feedback_1::eng: Try again! Making the instruction positive by telling @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name what she should do rather than shouldn‚Äôt do will help @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name to follow through.
instructions_articles.quiz_2_option_2_text::eng: She gives @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name a transition warning & follows through with what she said.
instructions_articles.quiz_2_feedback_2::eng: Correct! All these steps make it more likely that @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name follows @data.characters.f1_mother.name‚Äôs instruction. She also praises his daughter.
instructions_articles.quiz_2_option_3_text::eng: She makes @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name feel guilty for taking too long.
instructions_articles.quiz_2_feedback_3::eng: Try again! Making her feel guilty will mean it is harder for @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name to feel motivated to follow instructions both now and in the future. It will also feel stressful for @data.characters.f1_mother.name.
instructions_articles.quiz_2_option_4_text::eng: She tells her to stop playing and start cleaning.
instructions_articles.quiz_2_feedback_4::eng: Try again! She gives @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name a positive instruction to ‚Äúclean up‚Äù without giving a negative one of ‚Äústop playing.‚Äù
instructions_articles.quiz_3_question::eng: What would have happened if @data.characters.f1_mother.name had said: ‚Äú@data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name, stop playing with your blocks, and don‚Äôt go to bed with dirty teeth!‚Äù
instructions_articles.quiz_3_feedback_1::eng: Exactly. It is important to give one positive instruction at a time. It makes a big difference.
instructions_articles.quiz_3_feedback_2::eng: Try again! It‚Äôs important to give one positive instruction at a time. This will make the instruction easier to follow.

instructions_articles.text_1_facilitator::eng: Let‚Äôs look at another family to see how positive instructions can even help to prevent misbehaviour before it starts!
instructions_articles.text_2::eng: @data.characters.f2_grandfather.name is working in the garden while his granddaughter, @data.characters.f2_daughter_3.name and grandson, @data.characters.f2_son_8.name are playing with a ball:

Thank you for coming to help me. We are going to grow lots of delicious vegetables together.

instructions_articles.text_1_facilitator::eng: Let‚Äôs reflect on what @data.characters.f2_grandfather.name did here.
instructions_articles.quiz_1_question::eng: What would have happened if @data.characters.f2_grandfather.name had not paid attention to the children?
instructions_articles.quiz_1_option_1_text::eng: They would have continued  to argue.
instructions_articles.quiz_1_feedback_1::eng: Yes. The situation between the children would have gotten out of hand.These are all correct answers!
instructions_articles.quiz_1_option_2_text::eng: They could have hurt each other in the argument.
instructions_articles.quiz_1_feedback_2::eng: Yes. The children could have gotten so upset that they would have hurt each other. These are all correct answers!
instructions_articles.quiz_1_option_3_text::eng: @data.characters.f2_grandfather.name would have had to stop working in the garden.
instructions_articles.quiz_1_feedback_3::eng: Yes. If @data.characters.f2_grandfather.name had kept quiet, he would have had to spend more time and energy  trying to resolve the conflict. These are all correct answers!
instructions_articles.quiz_2_question::eng: What does @data.characters.f2_grandfather.name do to prevent the argument from getting out of hand?
instructions_articles.quiz_2_option_1_text::eng: He draws their attention away from the problem, involves them in a positive activity, and gives them praise.
instructions_articles.quiz_2_feedback_1::eng: That‚Äôs right. He quickly intervenes to distract them, and gives a positive instruction to redirect them to a positive behaviour.
instructions_articles.quiz_2_option_2_text::eng: He reminds them it‚Äôs important to get along.
instructions_articles.quiz_2_option_3_text::eng: He gives them a warning for a consequence.

instructions_articles.text_1_facilitator::eng: Here are three tips to give positive instructions that work:
instructions_articles.section_1_text::eng:
Say the behaviour you want your child to do.
But before you do that, connect to them, so they are more likely to listen.
instructions_articles.section_1_extra_text::eng:
Use your child‚Äôs name to get your child‚Äôs attention. Go down to their level. Make eye contact.

Then say exactly what you want them to do. For example: ‚ÄúPlease take your shoes off when you come inside, dear‚Äù
instructions_articles.section_2_text::eng:
Give one instruction at a time, and make sure that the instruction is something that your child can do. 

Giving a transition warning helps when you are asking them to change activities!
instructions_articles.section_2_extra_text::eng:
It can be difficult for your child to remember many instructions, so only give one at a time!

If possible, give a transition warning. For example: ‚ÄúIn 10 minutes, you will need to pack away your toys so we can start getting ready for bed.‚Äù
instructions_articles.section_3_text::eng:
Try using positive words when giving instructions. For example, instead of ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt shout inside,‚Äù say ‚ÄúTalk in a quiet voice when we‚Äôre inside.‚Äù

ALWAYS praise your child for following your instruction. Remember that this will make them more likely to repeat the behaviour you have just praised them for, and listen to you next time!
instructions_articles.section_3_extra_text::eng:
Give instructions in a firm voice and stay calm. Behave as if you expect your child to do what you ask.

Praise, praise, praise! Make sure you praise your child immediately when they follow your instruction.

Also, be kind to yourself if you forget sometimes. Learning how to give positive instructions is not easy, but it works!

instructions_articles.text_1_facilitator::eng: In order to practise giving instructions that work we all need to work on turning our negative instructions into positive ones.
instructions_articles.quiz_1_question::eng: Click on each of the negative commands to see how they can be restated as a positive instruction.
instructions_articles.quiz_1_option_1_text::eng: "Stop fighting with your siblings over toys!"
instructions_articles.quiz_1_feedback_1::eng: "Please take turns with toys! Each of you can have 5 minutes."
instructions_articles.quiz_1_feedback_2::eng: "Please speak with a quiet, indoor voice."
instructions_articles.quiz_1_feedback_3::eng: "Please keep your food on the plate."

instructions_articles.text_1_facilitator::eng:
Ready to give it a go? Try giving your child specific, realistic, and positive instructions. 

Remember to give one instruction at a time and praise them. This will help your child to follow your instructions.
instructions_articles.media_title::eng: How it helped a parent like you:
instructions_articles.media_transcript::eng:
Before, I used to raise my children the way I was raised: I would tell them ‚Äúdon‚Äôt do this, don‚Äôt do that.‚Äù We used to fight a lot, but things have really changed when I learned about giving positive instructions.

Now I focus on the behaviour I want to see, and give clear and simple instructions to my children. It took time to learn to say ‚Äúplease  do  this‚Äù instead of ‚Äú don‚Äôt  do this.‚Äù 
My children and even my husband tell me that they love this way of doing things, because now they know what needs to be done. My child said one day ‚ÄúI really love this new mom,‚Äù and my own stress levels have come down a lot.
instructions_articles.quiz_1_question::eng: Your home activity is to give your child positive instructions today. Can you do it?
instructions_articles.quiz_1_feedback_1::eng: Of course, you can! It might feel awkward at first, but you will get it soon! Keep up the excellent effort.
instructions_articles.quiz_1_feedback_2::eng: That's okay. It may take time to learn how to rephrase your requests. After the next request, you give your child, stop and imagine how it could be rephrased as a positive request. You‚Äôve got this!

rulesroutines_articles.text_1_facilitator::eng:
Today's lesson is about creating structure for our children.

Rules and routines help children understand what is expected from them, be responsible, and stay safe. 

Children are more likely to follow rules if you create them TOGETHER.  

Creating daily routines (around for example meals, school and bedtime) will help your child feel safe, secure, and calm.
rulesroutines_articles.media_title::eng: How will it help me and my family?
rulesroutines_articles.media_transcript::eng:
Greetings, everyone.

Does anybody else find getting their children ready for school or bed stressful?

Guess what? Rules can help! Having clear rules and routines actually helps children know what is expected of them, which helps reduce the struggles of the more stressful moments in the day.

rulesroutines_articles.text_1_facilitator::eng: Let‚Äôs look at an example together. @data.characters.f1_daughter_6.name is spending too much time watching TV before her homework is finished. @data.characters.f1_mother.name helps him create a family rule about this:
rulesroutines_articles.character_1_text::eng: It is important that you get your homework done so you can do well in school. Let‚Äôs make a rule about watching TV so that you have enough time for homework, too.‚Äù
What do you think would be a fair rule?
rulesroutines_articles.character_2_text::eng: Hmmm‚Ä¶well, maybe I can watch TV as much as I want, but only after I do my homework?

rulesroutines_articles.character_1_text::eng: I like that idea, but let‚Äôs limit it to 30 minutes per day so that you have time for other fun and relaxing things too. How does that sound?

Thank you for doing your homework before watching TV, @data.characters.f1_daughter_6.name. Last night you mentioned that your math tests have become easier for you! I am proud of you! We can increase your time to an hour each day‚Ä¶ as long as you still do your homework first!

rulesroutines_articles.text_1_facilitator::eng: Let‚Äôs reflect on how @data.characters.f1_mother.name and @data.characters.f1_daughter_6.name created a rule together.

rulesroutines_articles.quiz_1_feedback_1::eng: Correct. When you make rules together with your child, the rules will work better.
rulesroutines_articles.quiz_1_option_2_text::eng: To make it more likely that she follows the rule
rulesroutines_articles.quiz_1_feedback_2::eng: Correct. When you make rules together with your child, the rules will work better.
rulesroutines_articles.quiz_1_option_3_text::eng: To make her feel her ideas are valued
rulesroutines_articles.quiz_1_feedback_3::eng: Correct. When you make rules together with your child, the rules will work better.
rulesroutines_articles.quiz_1_option_4_text::eng: To make sure she feels the rule is fair and realistic
rulesroutines_articles.quiz_1_feedback_4::eng: Correct. When you make rules together with your child, the rules will work better.
rulesroutines_articles.quiz_2_question::eng: What does @data.characters.f1_mother.name do when @data.characters.f1_daughter_6.name follows the rule?
rulesroutines_articles.quiz_2_feedback_1::eng: Yes, by doing this @data.characters.f1_mother.name makes it more likely that @data.characters.f1_daughter_6.name will keep following the rule about TV watching.
rulesroutines_articles.quiz_2_option_2_text::eng: She gives her a simple reward
rulesroutines_articles.quiz_2_feedback_2::eng: Yes, by doing this @data.characters.f1_mother.name makes it more likely that @data.characters.f1_daughter_6.name will keep following the rules about TV watching.

rulesroutines_articles.text_1_facilitator::eng: Let‚Äôs look at another family. They have set up a routine around bedtime that is working really well!
rulesroutines_articles.character_1_text::eng: I am so happy to see you playing quietly with your building blocks, @data.characters.f2_daughter_3.name. In 5 minutes, it will be time to get ready for bed. When you are ready for bed, we can read a story together.
Time to get ready for bed, @data.characters.f2_daughter_3.name. First, let‚Äôs get you nice and clean with a bath.
You were so well-behaved in the bath, @data.characters.f2_daughter_3.name. Now it is time to put your pyjamas on.
Well done for putting on your pyjamas by yourself, @data.characters.f2_daughter_3.name! Now let‚Äôs brush your teeth. Make sure you get the ones in the back of your mouth too!
You did so well getting ready for bed! Now, we have time to read a story. Which book would you like to read?
rulesroutines_articles.character_2_text::eng: Yay! Can you read me the story about the lion?

rulesroutines_articles.character_1_text::eng: The end‚Ä¶.‚Äù I‚Äôm glad you chose that story for us to read, it‚Äôs one of my favourites! Goodnight, my dear. I love you very much.

rulesroutines_articles.text_1_facilitator::eng: Let‚Äôs think about what made this routine work well so we can all have peaceful bedtimes in our families.

Exactly. Being consistent with a routine ‚Äì especially at the end of the day when everyone is tired ‚Äì makes activities easier to follow for children. 

With a bit of practice, bedtime can become a happy time of connecting with your child!
rulesroutines_articles.quiz_2_question::eng: What does @data.characters.f2_grandmother.name do to help @data.characters.f2_daughter_3.name follow this routine?
rulesroutines_articles.quiz_2_option_1_text::eng: She praises and connects with @data.characters.f2_daughter_3.name before giving instructions
rulesroutines_articles.quiz_2_feedback_1::eng: Yes, praise helps encourage @data.characters.f2_daughter_3.name to follow the routine successfully.
rulesroutines_articles.quiz_2_option_2_text::eng: She promises @data.characters.f2_daughter_3.name a simple reward to encourage her
rulesroutines_articles.quiz_2_feedback_2::eng: Yes, the promise of a reward helped @data.characters.f2_daughter_3.name to follow the routine successfully.
rulesroutines_articles.quiz_2_option_3_text::eng: She gives @data.characters.f2_daughter_3.name a transition warning for each step of the routine.
rulesroutines_articles.quiz_2_feedback_3::eng: Yes, knowing which step comes next helps @data.characters.f2_daughter_3.name to follow the routine successfully.
rulesroutines_articles.quiz_2_option_4_text::eng: She gives @data.characters.f2_daughter_3.name one instruction at a time.
rulesroutines_articles.quiz_2_feedback_4::eng: Yes, one instruction at a time means @data.characters.f2_daughter_3.name doesn‚Äôt get confused and helps her to follow the routine successfully.
rulesroutines_articles.quiz_2_feedback_5::eng: Yes, praise will help @data.characters.f2_daughter_3.name to remember how to follow the routine successfully next time, and encourage her to follow the next step.

rulesroutines_articles.text_1_facilitator::eng: These four tips will help you create rules and routines to bring more structure and peace in your home:
rulesroutines_articles.section_1_text::eng: When you involve your child in making rules they are more likely to follow them. One rule at a time is easiest.
rulesroutines_articles.section_1_extra_text::eng:
Plan rules WITH your child. Discuss the reasons for the rule and ask about their ideas.

Older children can share their own ideas of what they think the rule should be and you can agree together. They will feel appreciated and heard.
rulesroutines_articles.section_2_text::eng:
Consider your child‚Äôs age and developmental level when creating rules and routines. They have to be able to do what is expected of them.

Remember: Only introduce one new rule or routine at a time ‚Äì you can add another one later.
rulesroutines_articles.section_2_extra_text::eng: Make rules and routines realistic for what your child can actually do and specific so there is no misunderstanding. Don‚Äôt say ‚Äú ‚Äúclean up‚Äù but ‚Äúpick up all of your blocks‚Äù.
rulesroutines_articles.section_3_text::eng:
Make sure your child follows the rules and routines daily.

That way, your child knows what to expect and this will help them to feel secure. They will learn to be more independent and responsible.
rulesroutines_articles.section_3_extra_text::eng: Activities become easier when children learn and get used to a routine.

rulesroutines_articles.text_1_facilitator::eng: Let‚Äôs come up with some ideas for rules and routines in your home.
rulesroutines_articles.text_2::eng: Here are some of the rules and routines that other families created.
rulesroutines_articles.quiz_1_question::eng: Would you like to try one of these  rules  with your child?
rulesroutines_articles.quiz_1_option_1_text::eng: Your child can play after finishing homework.
rulesroutines_articles.quiz_1_feedback_1::eng: This is a great rule! Discuss it with your child and family, or come up with a different rule that will help you at home.
rulesroutines_articles.quiz_1_option_2_text::eng: All family members eat dinner together.
rulesroutines_articles.quiz_1_feedback_2::eng: This is a great rule! Discuss it with your child and family, or come up with a different rule that will help you at home.
rulesroutines_articles.quiz_1_option_3_text::eng: Your child helps to clear the dishes after dinner.
rulesroutines_articles.quiz_1_feedback_3::eng: This is a great rule! Discuss it with your child and family, or come up with a different rule that will help you at home.
rulesroutines_articles.quiz_1_option_4_text::eng: Your child packs away the toys they played with during the day before bedtime
rulesroutines_articles.quiz_1_feedback_4::eng: This is a great rule! Discuss it with your child and family, or come up with a different rule that will help you at home.
rulesroutines_articles.quiz_2_question::eng: In which of these areas would you like to create routines  with your child?
rulesroutines_articles.quiz_2_feedback_1::eng: Wonderful! Give it a try and see how it will change your relationship with your child.
rulesroutines_articles.quiz_2_feedback_2::eng: Wonderful! Give it a try and see how it will change your relationship with your child. Remember bedtime routines work best when they are predictable and calm!
rulesroutines_articles.quiz_2_feedback_3::eng: Wonderful! Give it a try and see how it will change your relationship with your child. Remember to use positive instructions when setting up this routine.
rulesroutines_articles.quiz_2_feedback_4::eng: Wonderful! Give it a try and see how it will change your relationship with your child. Remember that mealtime routines work best when they are predictable.
rulesroutines_articles.quiz_2_feedback_5::eng: Wonderful! Remember to praise for following through on chore routines! Give it a try and see how it will change your relationship with your child.
rulesroutines_articles.quiz_2_feedback_6::eng: Wonderful! Give it a try and see how it will change your relationship with your child.

rulesroutines_articles.text_1_facilitator::eng:
Your home activity is to set *one* rule and *one* routine with your child. 

Remember to be realistic and consistent, and praise your child for following each rule or routine!
rulesroutines_articles.media_title::eng: How it helped a parent like you:
rulesroutines_articles.media_transcript::eng:
Bedtime was always a struggle in our house. My children wanted to keep watching TV and I would always end up shouting at them: ‚ÄúGo to bed now! You know you have to be ready for school early in the morning!‚Äù. Some days I was just too tired, and I would let them watch more TV. 

When we learned in @global.app_name about rules, I learned that it is important to be consistent. I discussed with my children why watching TV till late is a problem, and we came up with a rule together to switch off the TV at 8 and be ready for bed by 8.30. Now everyone knows what is expected of them, and we can end the day peacefully.
rulesroutines_articles.quiz_1_question::eng: Can you set one routine and one rule with your child?
rulesroutines_articles.quiz_1_feedback_1::eng: That's great! I hope it makes your home feel easier to manage for everyone.
rulesroutines_articles.quiz_1_feedback_2::eng: That's okay. Setting rules is hard and including children can feel uncomfortable, especially if you‚Äôre not used to it. Keep trying until you find a way that works for you and your children. I promise, it will be worth it!

consequences_articles.text_1_facilitator::eng:
Today's lesson is about helping our children follow instructions and rules by using consequences

Consequences are the results of actions and behaviours. Parents can use a planned consequence when children don‚Äôt follow a rule or instruction. 

For example if a child doesn‚Äôt follow the rule to come home from playing at 6pm, then a consequence could be that the child can‚Äôt go out to play the next day. 

Giving clear consequences teaches children that their actions affect themselves and others.
consequences_articles.media_title::eng: How will it help me and my family?
consequences_articles.media_transcript::eng:
We all misbehave sometimes! 

As parents, we are also sometimes tempted to scream and shout when our children misbehave. But that just makes everything worse for everyone.

If we stay calm and give our children a consequence instead, they start to learn to take responsibility for their actions and we avoid the anger that comes with hitting or shouting.

consequences_articles.text_1_facilitator::eng:
Some consequences happen naturally (if they break a toy, they cannot play with it). 

Other consequences you will set. These consequences will help your child follow the rules (if you do not pack away your toys, you won‚Äôt be allowed to play with them tomorrow).

consequences_articles.text_1_facilitator::eng: Here are some easy steps to use consequences when your child misbehaves:
consequences_articles.section_1_text::eng:
Take some deep breaths or walk away from the situation if you need to.

Then, respond in a calm, clear way.
consequences_articles.section_1_extra_text::eng: Shouting at our children only makes things worse. It also teaches them that it is okay to treat others like this when they are upset.
consequences_articles.section_2_text::eng:
Before giving a consequence, give your child the choice to behave and time to do what you asked.

Give a consequence connected to the behaviour, and make sure it is something you can follow through with.
consequences_articles.section_2_extra_text::eng:
For example, if they do not clean up their toys, they cannot play with them the next day (rather than the whole week).

If your child is experiencing a natural consequence for their action already (like not being able to play with their toy after breaking it), you might not need to give them an additional consequence.
consequences_articles.section_3_text::eng:
It is important to follow through with consequences for the rules you have set, every time they do not follow them.

This helps your child to know what to expect, and makes it more likely that they will follow the rule.
consequences_articles.section_3_extra_text::eng: Talk about consequences for breaking household rules when you create these rules, so that your child knows them and sticks to them.
consequences_articles.section_4_text::eng: Involve your children in planning consequences for certain behaviours.
consequences_articles.section_4_extra_text::eng: Discuss what a consequence could be if children do not follow a certain household rule when they are creating it with them.

consequences_articles.text_1_facilitator::eng: Let‚Äôs come up with some ideas for reasonable and realistic consequences.
consequences_articles.quiz_1_question::eng: Would any of these consequences be helpful for you and your child?
consequences_articles.quiz_1_option_1_text::eng: If you are late for dinner, your food will be cold.

consequences_articles.quiz_1_option_2_text::eng: If you continue splashing water out of the bath, bath time will be over.
consequences_articles.quiz_1_feedback_2::eng: Great. Discuss this (or another) consequence with your child and family, and try it out together.
consequences_articles.quiz_1_option_3_text::eng: If you break your toy, you will have no toy to play with.
consequences_articles.quiz_1_feedback_3::eng: Great. Discuss this (or another) consequence with your child and family, and try it out together.
consequences_articles.quiz_1_option_4_text::eng: If you can‚Äôt play close to home where I can see you, then you will have to come inside.
consequences_articles.quiz_1_feedback_4::eng: Great. Discuss this (or another) consequence with your child and family, and try it out together.
consequences_articles.quiz_1_option_5_text::eng: If you do not put away your toys before you go to bed, then you cannot play with them tomorrow morning.
consequences_articles.quiz_1_feedback_5::eng: Great. Discuss this (or another) consequence with your child and family, and try it out tomorrow.
consequences_articles.quiz_1_option_6_text::eng: None of these will work in my home.
consequences_articles.quiz_1_feedback_6::eng: That's okay! Try to think of just one consequence that you feel confident you can follow-through with in a calm way. Try starting with something small.

consequences_articles.text_1_facilitator::eng:
Remember that praising your child for the things you would like them to keep doing is a good way to see more positive behaviour in your home. 

Using fair and realistic consequences is also part of building a positive relationship with your child.

Your home activity is to have a discussion with your child about one persistent challenging household rule and discuss a possible consequence.

problemsolving_articles.text_1_facilitator::eng:
I'M HUNGRY! HE HIT ME! I'M BORED!
Sound familiar? 

Every family faces big and small challenges. Learning how to solve problems together with your child can help you prevent conflict in your home. 

It also teaches your children how to solve problems on their own. 

This will set them up for success throughout their life. What a gift!
problemsolving_articles.media_title::eng: How will it help me and my family?
problemsolving_articles.media_transcript::eng:
Greetings, everyone.

As parents, it can feel like we have to solve a million problems for our children every day: Where is my toy car? I am not going to school! Why can‚Äôt you buy me new shoes now?

By involving our children in solving problems, they learn to find solutions more and more independently. 

Life has its challenges. If you help your child solve small problems today, you give them the skills to deal with any bigger challenges later in life.

problemsolving_articles.text_1_facilitator::eng:
When a problem comes up, take a deep breath before you tackle it. 

Then help your child work on the problem with you using these four steps:
problemsolving_articles.section_1_text::eng:
Put the problem into words.

Talk to your child about what the problem is.
problemsolving_articles.section_1_extra_text::eng: "I can hear you arguing because you don‚Äôt want to watch the same television programme. I know I said you both could watch TV after you‚Äôve helped clean up after dinner but we only have one television set. What should we do about this?"
problemsolving_articles.section_2_text::eng:
Together, think of possible solutions to this problem.
What could you or your child do differently in this situation in the future?
problemsolving_articles.section_2_extra_text::eng: "One option is for us not to turn the television on at all. Or you could take turns choosing a programme. Or you could select a programme you both want to watch. What do you both think?"
problemsolving_articles.section_3_text::eng:
Choose one solution together.

Try it next time you are in a similar situation, and praise your child for trying!
problemsolving_articles.section_3_extra_text::eng:
The next day at after the dinner dishes are clean...
"Okay boys, do you remember what we said last night about the TV? Who can remember the solution we came up with?"
"That's right ‚Äì well done for remembering! Let's try to pick a programme that you both want to watch ‚Äì I may even come watch with you!"
problemsolving_articles.section_4_text::eng: After you‚Äôve tried it, decide with your child whether or not your solution worked.
problemsolving_articles.section_4_extra_text::eng: After the programme ends... "Well that was an exciting game! I never knew I liked watching soccer so much, so thank you for introducing me to something new! I think we all had fun watching that together, so I look forward to seeing what you pick to watch tomorrow."

problemsolving_articles.text_1_facilitator::eng:
Your home activity is to identify a problem your child may have and practise the four steps of problem-solving together: 
Know It, Solve It, Try It, Reflect. 

Knowing how to solve problems is something they can use for the rest of their lives!
problemsolving_articles.media_title::eng: How it helped a parent like you:
problemsolving_articles.media_transcript::eng:
I did not have a good relationship with my daughter. I was always shouting at her, and she was refusing to go to school. 

Only when I started spending One-on-One Time with her, I realised that she did not want to go to school because she was being bullied at school. We sat down and used the four steps of problem solving. We identified the problem, and figured out solutions together: ‚ÄúWhat can I do as a parent so you can attend school and feel safe?‚Äù

We agreed I would go talk to the teacher to find a way forward. We really found the solutions together, and we are closer now.
